image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

props.synopsis: A new COVID variant nicknamed "Pirola" has been detected in Australia after sparking a sped-up vaccination program in the United Kingdom.

title.children: The 'highly mutated' COVID variant BA.2.86 — known as Pirola — has landed in Australia

image.altText: Two women and one man stand in front of a banner and artwork.

props.synopsis: Legal advocates hope a new pilot program, one of three nationwide, will encourage more people to report allegations of sexual violence and feel supported through the criminal justice system.

title.children: 'A tough few years': Dedicated legal service for sexual assault complainants begins trial in Canberra

image.altText: Peopole of all ages are walking outdoors, wearing blue surgical masks.

props.synopsis: An inquiry is set to be announced into the state, territory and federal governments' response to the COVID-19 pandemic.

title.children: Government to launch inquiry into federal, state and territory response to pandemic

image.altText: Gregor and Irma Palasics

props.synopsis: For 24 years, ACT police have followed often false leads in their quest to find the two men responsible for the brutal killing of Irma Palasics in 1999. Now, they say one of those men is behind bars.

title.children: The twists and turns of the investigation into Irma's murder have finally led to an answer

image.altText: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addresses a high level Security Council meeting.

props.synopsis: Ukraine President Volodymyr Zelenskyy takes the floor at the UN Security Council to lash 'criminal' Russia before foreign secretary Sergei Lavrov unloads for Russia.

title.children: As Russia ignores Zelenskyy at UN they're reminded they 'can stop the war' any time they like

image.altText: Airbnb logo on a pink background with silhouetted figurines of travellers with bags in the foreground

props.synopsis: If there's a lesson from the evolution of the gig economy, it's that we don't yet know how AI will disrupt our economy and our lives. But it's at least worth considering potential impacts and contemplating sensible rules of the road early on, writes David Speers.

title.children: Eight years ago, Airbnb was a new platform with a hidden dark side. Now the warnings are sounding again

image.altText: Von der Leyen can be seen in focus in between soldiers

props.synopsis: A former musician who was once forced to go into hiding from terrorists, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen's path to power has been an incredible journey.

title.children: How a young girl destined to become a 'housewife at the side of a powerful man' instead grew up to lead Europe through crisis

image.altText: Barnaby Joyce speaks at a press conference, where journalists hold microphones. Other politicians stand behind him.

props.synopsis: An unlikely coalition of Australian parliamentarians converges on Washington to lobby US decision-makers to drop the legal pursuit of Julian Assange and grant his freedom by Christmas.

title.children: 'We came here to get a resolution': Australian MPs lobby Washington for Assange's freedom

image.altText: LeBron James stands in front of a white board.

props.synopsis: Five years ago, LeBron James set out to fix some of America's most difficult problems. Some question whether the project is living up to its promises.

title.children: LeBron James set out to revolutionise America’s broken school system. Then the results came in

image.altText: A baby being held with an arm around her head and a line with dots on her back. A white peg is being pushed on their back.

props.synopsis: Australia has some of the highest rates of food allergy in the world but the way we test for these potentially fatal conditions is unreliable and leading to misdiagnoses, say experts.

title.children: 'A real problem for us as allergists': why experts don't recommend the skin prick test to screen for allergies

image.altText: Tennis fans cool off at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: As Australia prepares for hot and dry months after the declaration of an El Niño, a stark reminder of the increasing danger posed by heatwaves in Australia's southern cities may lie ahead.

title.children: El Niño is likely to bring a scorching summer. These cities might feel it most

image.altText: fire crews at blaze spray water on fire

props.synopsis: A petrol station has exploded into flames after gas cylinders caught alight as crews worked to save neighbouring homes in Sydney's west.

title.children: Motorist describes the moment a Sydney petrol station caught fire while he was filling up

image.altText: Eddie Jones looks pensive after the Wallabies lost to Fiji at the 2023 Rugby World Cup.

props.synopsis: Retired Test winger Drew Mitchell blames veteran coach Eddie Jones for putting the Wallabies in danger of missing the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals for the first time.

title.children: Ex-Wallaby unloads expletive-loaded criticism on Eddie Jones as World Cup campaign hangs by a thread

image.altText: Wind turbines are set to dot the landscape in Victoria's west

props.synopsis: Some experts are warning Australia's ambitions to have zero carbon emissions by 2050 need to be scaled up dramatically.

title.children: Reaching net zero by 2035 would take a 'gargantuan' effort. But these experts say our current 2050 target is just too far away

image.altText: an aboriginal man wearing traditional dress

props.synopsis: A respected religious leader from north-east Arnhem Land wants the No campaign to retract his image from its campaign material and publicly announce that it has done so.

title.children: 'No consent': Arnhem Land elder calls for Fair Australia to retract his image from campaign material

image.altText: Joanne Baker stacking a fridge with soft drinks

props.synopsis: As debate over the Voice continues around the country, locals in this remote South Australian community are focused on issues closer to home.

title.children: This town only has enough jobs for 15 per cent of locals. The community is working to change that

image.altText: George RR Martin

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happens.

title.children: Game of Thrones author George RR Martin sues OpenAI for 'systematic theft', Australia urges US to let Julian Assange walk free. Get in The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Experts are warning people to be more cautious of scammers, after nearly 200,000 Pizza Hut Australia customers have had their data leaked in a cyber attack. A spokesperson says they became aware of the hack — where an unauthorised third party accessed some of the company's data — earlier this month. Pizza Hut says it believes the data stolen includes customers' names, delivery address and instructions, email address and contact number — but no payment details. Stan Gallo is a forensic services partner at consultancy firm BDO, and says it's likely people will see more text messages and emails from scammers. "And that won't necessarily come from someone pretending to be Pizza Hut," he says. "If they've got your contact details I might get a message that purports to come from you for example. So, those sorts of thing will rise and people need to be cautious of those." Mr Gallo suggests setting up a separate email address as one way to thwart scammers. "You can redirect some of that unwanted traffic, and one that you wouldn't use elsewhere. And I'd tie that to the old addage of not using the same password," he says. "In this case, I don't believe passwords were affected. But you could also tie that with using a card for those purchases with a very low balance."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Pizza Hut Australia customers warned about scammers after cyber attack

children.content: (ABC News: Andrea Mayes)
Experts are warning people to be more cautious of scammers, after nearly 200,000 Pizza Hut Australia customers have had their data leaked in a cyber attack.
A spokesperson says they became aware of the hack — where an unauthorised third party accessed some of the company's data — earlier this month.
Pizza Hut says it believes the data stolen includes customers' names, delivery address and instructions, email address and contact number — but no payment details.
Stan Gallo is a forensic services partner at consultancy firm BDO, and says it's likely people will see more text messages and emails from scammers.
"And that won't necessarily come from someone pretending to be Pizza Hut," he says.
"If they've got your contact details I might get a message that purports to come from you for example. So, those sorts of thing will rise and people need to be cautious of those."
Mr Gallo suggests setting up a separate email address as one way to thwart scammers.
"You can redirect some of that unwanted traffic, and one that you wouldn't use elsewhere. And I'd tie that to the old addage of not using the same password," he says.
"In this case, I don't believe passwords were affected. But you could also tie that with using a card for those purchases with a very low balance."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: An inquiry is set to be announced into the state, territory and federal governments' response to the COVID-19 pandemic. Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Health Minister Mark Butler will announce the inquiry in Adelaide this morning. The ABC understands the inquiry will not have the same powers as a royal commission but will be able to call witnesses and examine the response of federal, state and territory governments during the pandemic. The inquiry will cover all responses since the COVID-19 pandemic began in January 2020. The terms of the inquiry will be further fleshed out by the prime minister and Mr Butler but the ABC understands the probe will be led by medical experts. You can follow the latest updates on this below:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Anthony Albanese to announce inquiry into COVID-19 response

featuredLink.title: Government to launch inquiry into federal, state and territory response to pandemic

children.content: An inquiry is set to be announced into the state, territory and federal governments' response to the COVID-19 pandemic.
Prime Minister Anthony Albanese and Health Minister Mark Butler will
announce the inquiry in Adelaide this morning.
The ABC understands the inquiry will not have the same powers as a royal commission but will be able to call witnesses and examine the response of federal, state and territory governments during the
pandemic.
The inquiry will cover all responses since the COVID-19 pandemic began in January 2020.
The terms of the inquiry will be further fleshed out by the prime minister and Mr Butler but the ABC understands the probe
will be led by medical experts.
You can follow the latest updates on this below:

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Authorities in New South Wales say it will take several days to bring fires under control as a cool change moves through the state. The north-western region of the state is under a total fire ban today, with hot and windy conditions forecast. More than 60 fires are still burning following above-average September heat during the first half of the week. Meanwhile, fire crews in Queensland are on stand-by for worsening conditions today, with parts of the coast expecting record temperatures of 40C. There are total fire bans for the Barcoo shire in the state's south-west. Queensland has been battling multiple bushfires since the weekend, with a firefighting helicopter pilot having a lucky escape after crashing into a dam.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Fire authorities in Queensland and NSW still on high alert

children.content: (Supplied: QFES)

Queensland has been battling multiple bushfires since the weekend, with
a firefighting helicopter pilot having a lucky escape
after crashing into a dam.

props.synopsis: Catastrophic fire danger warnings have been issued in parts of Australia already as it enters a hotter and drier than average climate pattern. If the fire season has taken you by surprise, here's a reminder of how the warning system works.

title.children: What makes a bushfire alert 'catastrophic', and how should you respond?

image.altText: Jerome Powell stands at a podium behind a wall of American flags.

props.synopsis: Former chair of the ACCC to oversee an inquiry into Price Gouging and Unfair Pricing Practices, while a fall on Wall Street is likely to send Australian stocks lower today. Follow the latest updates in our live blog.

title.children: Former ACCC chair Fels probes price gouging, US Fed holds interest rates steady, ASX to fall

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Professor Allan Fels is chairing the ACTU hearing to examine Price Gouging and Unfair Pricing Practices. He's addressed the media ahead of the start of the inquiry. Professor Fels said they've have 600 submissions. Food and drink, energy and banking and insurance are among the most common issues brought up in those submissions. He said he he was keen to do the inquiry because there hasn't bene enough consideration on how prices are set by business and the impact of those rising prices on consumers. He said there's evidence profit markups have gone up and competition has been reduced, both here ad overseas. He says that gives him cause for concern.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Former ACCC chair Professor Allan Fels is speaking ahead of the inquiry

children.content: Professor Allan Fels
is chairing the ACTU hearing to examine
Price Gouging and Unfair Pricing Practices
He's addressed the media ahead of the start of the inquiry.
Professor Fels said they've have
600 submissions.
Food and drink, energy and banking and insurance
are among the most common issues brought up in those submissions.
He said he he was keen to do the inquiry because
there hasn't bene enough consideration on how prices are set by business and the impact of those rising prices on consumers
He said there's
evidence profit markups have gone up
and
competition has been reduced
, both here ad overseas.
He says that gives him cause for concern.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Hi blog readers. I'm jumping in here to help out Sam cover the ACTU inquiry. We're a team of multitaskers and Sam has a few other things to get on with so you've got me for the rest of the day. Thanks for following along so far. I hope you'll stay with me. As always, we love to hear from you, so please pop any questions or comments into the box at the top. I'll be back in just a moment with more activity from price-gouging inquiry.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Hello it's me

children.content: Hi blog readers. I'm jumping in here to help out Sam cover the ACTU inquiry.
We're a team of multitaskers and Sam has a few other things to get on with so you've got me for the rest of the day.
Thanks for following along so far. I hope you'll stay with me.
As always, we love to hear from you, so please pop any questions or comments into the box at the top.
I'll be back in just a moment with more activity from price-gouging inquiry.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ACTU has commissioned an inquiry into price gouging and unfair pricing practices, chaired by Allan Fels, a former chair of the ACCC. This is the first day of hearings and will cover a number of industries including petrol, energy, insurance and groceries. Professor Fels will speak at 9:30am AEST at a press conference in Melbourne. We will cover this inquiry for you as it happens. Stay tuned.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Upcoming inquiry into price gouging and unfair pricing practices

children.content: The ACTU has commissioned an inquiry into price gouging and unfair pricing practices, chaired by Allan Fels, a former chair of the ACCC.
This is the first day of hearings and will cover a number of industries including
petrol, energy, insurance and groceries
Professor Fels will speak at 9:30am AEST at a press conference in Melbourne.
We will cover this inquiry for you as it happens. Stay tuned.

image.altText: A jar of honey is filled using an automatic dispenser

props.synopsis: Research into varroa mite is expected to surge after Australia waved the white flag in its fight to eradicate the pest from New South Wales, a decision that is also expected to increase beekeeping costs.

image.altText: Vapour pours from a mill chimney behind power poles.

image.altText: A group of women wearing hijabs and masks walk through a colourful outdoor market.

title.children: Women in Iran may face 10 years jail for not wearing hijab under proposed new laws

image.altText: A post office as seen through the windscreen of a car at night.
